study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence rates to a behavioral therapy sleep intervention (including modified sleep restriction) and identify psychological and physical symptom predictors of adherence in women undergoing breast cancer chemotherapy.
results_summary: Adherence rates to the BT plan were 51-52% across treatments, with sleep disturbance and depression significantly impacting adherence. Sleep disturbance and pain decreased, while depression increased during chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Women with stages I-IIIA breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy (n = 113).
effective_dosage: Not specified (components included stimulus control, modified sleep restriction, relaxation therapy, and sleep hygiene counseling).
study_duration: Intervention began 48 hours before the first of four chemotherapy treatments and was reinforced on day 8, repeated for cycles 2, 3, and 4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction affects the efficacy of a reduced-calorie diet on fat loss and fat-free body mass preservation.
results_summary: Sleep restriction reduced the proportion of fat loss by 55% and increased fat-free body mass loss by 60%, alongside increased hunger and altered substrate utilization favoring less fat oxidation.
population_specificity: 10 overweight nonsmoking adults (3 women, 7 men; mean age 41, BMI 27.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 8.5 vs. 5.5 hours of nighttime sleep opportunity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review epidemiologic evidence linking habitual sleep duration and quality to the risk of cardiometabolic diseases, including obesity, diabetes, and hypertension.
results_summary: The study found cross-sectional associations between short sleep duration (<6 h per night) and increased body mass index, prevalent diabetes, and hypertension, as well as associations between long sleep duration (>8 h per night) and cardiometabolic disease. Some prospective studies also linked short sleep to incident diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease markers, though results were not entirely consistent.
population_specificity: General population (epidemiologic review, not a specific cohort)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the research support for psychological treatments of insomnia, including sleep restriction, and describe those with the highest level of evidence for clinical use.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was identified as one of the psychological treatments with research support for adult insomnia, though it was not among the top-tier interventions (stimulus control, progressive muscle relaxation, and multimodal cognitive-behavioral therapy were ranked higher).
population_specificity: Adults and children with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how sleep restriction and circadian misalignment in shift workers may increase neuroendocrine stress, immune responses, and oxidative stress, contributing to cardiovascular disease and breast cancer risks.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction and circadian misalignment disrupt neuroendocrine, immune, and oxidative stress systems, potentially increasing cardiovascular and breast cancer risks in shift workers. It also suggested napping as a potential countermeasure to mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Shift workers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction reduces insulin sensitivity and to assess the effects of modafinil on alertness during sleep restriction.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (5 h/night for 1 week) significantly reduced insulin sensitivity by 20% (IVGTT) and 11% (clamp), impaired glucose tolerance, and lowered the disposition index, without significant effects from modafinil treatment.
population_specificity: 20 healthy men aged 20-35 years with a BMI of 20-30 kg/m².
study_duration: 12-day inpatient study (10 h/night for ≥8 nights, then 5 h/night for 7 nights).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolic and endocrine effects of chronic partial sleep loss and its potential role in obesity.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction leads to metabolic and endocrine alterations, including decreased glucose tolerance, increased cortisol levels, altered hunger hormones, and increased appetite, suggesting a link to obesity.
population_specificity: Adults, children, and young adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 8 weekly sessions of sleep restriction therapy combined with hypnotic reduction instructions would improve sleep outcomes and reduce hypnotic use more effectively than sleep hygiene education alone.
results_summary: The sleep restriction plus hypnotic withdrawal group showed greater improvements in hypnotic medication usage, sleep onset latency, morning wake time, sleep efficiency, and wake time after sleep onset compared to the sleep hygiene-only group. These improvements were maintained at 6- and 12-month follow-ups.
population_specificity: 46 men and women recruited from a sleep medicine practice.
effective_dosage: 8 weekly sessions of sleep restriction therapy.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), including sleep restriction, in patients with non-malignant chronic pain.
results_summary: CBT-I significantly improved sleep continuity (reduced sleep latency, wake after sleep onset, and number of awakenings, increased sleep efficiency) and reduced insomnia severity and pain interference, though no significant changes were observed in mood or pain severity measures.
population_specificity: 28 subjects with chronic neck and back pain, stratified by gender, age, and ethnicity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (CBT-I included sleep restriction, stimulus control, sleep hygiene, and cognitive therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on the bidirectional relationship between disordered sleep and pain/fatigue, particularly in rheumatic diseases.
results_summary: The studies showed that sleep disturbances and sleep restriction increase sensitivity to pain and musculoskeletal symptoms, and that disordered sleep reduces neurophysiologic inhibition of pain perception. Sleep disturbances also directly influence fatigue, mood, and overall well-being.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatic illnesses, including fibromyalgia syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the analgesic effects of codeine are modulated by basal sleepiness-alertness levels induced by sleep restriction.
results_summary: The study found that codeine increased finger withdrawal latency (reduced nociception) in nonsleepy individuals but not in sleepy individuals, indicating diminished analgesic effects in sleep-restricted participants. The results suggest that basal sleepiness-alertness state influences clinical responses to analgesics.
population_specificity: 12 healthy adults aged 18-35 with sleep efficiencies >80%, divided into sleepy (MSLT <8 min) and nonsleepy (MSLT ≥8 min) groups.
effective_dosage: Codeine 30 mg b.i.d. (0900 and 1300) or placebo b.i.d.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the influence of daytime sleep supplementation on cardiovascular reactivity in response to psychological stress.
results_summary: Participants who accrued more than 45 minutes of daytime sleep showed significantly lower mean arterial pressure during the recovery phase of a stress reactivity task, suggesting improved cardiovascular recovery. The findings indicate potential cardiovascular benefits from daytime sleep.
population_specificity: Generally healthy young adults (N=85).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the frequency and types of smoking cessation interventions offered to people with cardiovascular disease (CVD) and assess their association with successful cessation, particularly among those with mental illness.
results_summary: Smoking cessation education was common, but evidence-based interventions like pharmacological support were low. Interventions were associated with higher cessation rates, but individuals with mental illness were less likely to quit. Financial incentives under QOF increased documentation but not intensive support or treatment.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with coronary heart disease (CHD) or stroke, including those with common and serious mental illness.
study_duration: Retrospective analysis spanning 1996-2019, with one-year follow-up post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a smoking cessation intervention delivered in emergency departments.
results_summary: The study found that the smoking cessation intervention in emergency departments helped people quit smoking, demonstrating statistically significant and clinically meaningful outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients in emergency departments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation and effectiveness of a one-year smoking cessation intervention (KISMET) in Dutch ambulatory mental healthcare settings.
results_summary: The intervention components (group sessions, peer support, pharmacological treatment) were generally viewed positively, though inconsistent group attendance and high drop-out rates (58%) were challenges. Carbon monoxide monitoring was unexpectedly motivational, while staff shortages and turnover hindered implementation.
population_specificity: Patients in Dutch ambulatory mental healthcare settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the causal relationship between educational attainment (years of schooling, cognitive performance, intelligence) and the risk of developing COPD, with a focus on mediating factors like smoking and asthma.
results_summary: The study found that longer years of schooling, higher cognitive performance, and intelligence were causally associated with a reduced risk of COPD. Smoking initiation and asthma were identified as significant mediating factors, accounting for 32.8% and 6.9% of the reduction in COPD risk, respectively.
population_specificity: General population (data obtained from genome-wide association studies).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of pharmacological therapies for smoking cessation in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Pharmacotherapy significantly increased continuous abstinence rates at 12 and 24 weeks, with varenicline showing effectiveness at 52 weeks. Adverse events were more frequent with varenicline but not significantly different from placebo.
population_specificity: Adult smokers with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of non-pharmacological school-based interventions for smoking cessation among adolescents in South and Southeast Asian countries.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that non-pharmacological school-based therapies significantly increased smoking abstinence compared to controls, with an odds ratio of 2.83. Subgroup analyses showed benefits across different study designs and follow-up durations, though effectiveness varied based on methodological factors.
population_specificity: Adolescents in South and Southeast Asian countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of smoking status on clinical outcomes, including mortality and liver-related complications, in patients with MASLD and MetALD.
results_summary: Current smokers had significantly higher mortality rates and incidences of liver cirrhosis and CVD compared to previous and never smokers. Never smokers showed the lowest incidence of hepatic decompensation and HCC in the MASLD cohort, while no significant differences were observed in the MetALD cohort.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and metabolic dysfunction and alcohol-associated liver disease (MetALD) from the UK Biobank.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a Health Belief Model-based integrated health education and mobile phone short message service intervention on improving health knowledge, perception, and self-efficacy toward smoking among industrial workers in Myanmar.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved health knowledge, perceived susceptibility, severity, barriers, benefits, and self-efficacy immediately after the 3-month training, though health knowledge slightly declined 3 months post-training. Generalized Estimating Equations confirmed significant positive effects across all measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Industrial workers in Mandalay Industrial Zone, Myanmar.
effective_dosage: Six health education sessions and daily short message service with weekly repeated content.
study_duration: 3 months of intervention, with follow-up 3 months post-training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore barriers, facilitators, and recommendations related to the intensive smoking cessation Gold Standard Programme (GSP) from the perspectives of patients, relatives, and clinicians in a urology setting.
results_summary: All participants perceived the GSP positively, with five categories of barriers and facilitators identified. Facilitators were similar across groups, while barriers varied. Clinicians faced challenges with relational and communicative factors, and patients and clinicians had differing recommendations for the GSP.
population_specificity: Patients treated with transurethral resection of the bladder tumour (TURBT), their relatives, and clinicians in the urology setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of an 8-week smoking cessation intervention combining nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) and gain-framed text messaging for individuals undergoing lung cancer screening (LCS).
results_summary: The intervention group showed modest quit rates (14.3% at Week 8 and 4.8% at 3-month follow-up) compared to 0% in the control group, though results were not statistically significant. The study highlights the need for more effective cessation strategies for LCS patients.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 64.4) undergoing lung cancer screening, 32.5% Black or African American, 55% female.
effective_dosage: Combination NRT (patches and lozenges), exact dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of pharmacological vs. non-pharmacological technology-supported smoking cessation interventions on adult daily smokers and their related health benefits.
results_summary: Non-pharmacological technology-supported interventions showed similar effectiveness and higher adherence at 6 months compared to pharmacological interventions. At 12 months, continuous abstinence rates were similar despite lower adherence in the non-pharmacological group.
population_specificity: Adult daily smokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and operationalize the 5A-QUIT-N intervention to promote smoking cessation in pregnant women by optimizing existing resources and improving coordination among healthcare professionals.
results_summary: The study found that better mobilization and coordination of existing resources are needed to address smoking cessation in pregnant women. The 5A-QUIT-N intervention was designed to enhance healthcare professionals' skills and improve regional resource organization for smoking cessation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Europe.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of LINE-based multidisciplinary team (MDT) interventions in improving COPD management for hospitalized patients.
results_summary: The study found that LINE-based MDT care significantly improved intervention rates and BSRS scores but did not significantly affect readmission rates, emergency room visits, or one-year survival.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with COPD admitted for exacerbations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of smoking on stem cell biology and explore advancements in stem cell-based therapies for smoking-induced diseases.
results_summary: The study found that smoking severely compromises stem cell function, particularly in tissue regeneration, but stem cell-based therapies, especially mesenchymal stem cells, show promise in repairing damage and reducing inflammation in smoking-related conditions like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
population_specificity: Chronic smokers and stem cell populations (e.g., mesenchymal, neural, hematopoietic stem cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of esketamine (ESK) for smoking cessation in patients with lung cancer and major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: ESK significantly improved self-reported and biologically verified continuous abstinence rates, alleviated depression and anxiety severity, improved cognitive function, and reduced nicotine dependence, urge to smoke, and respiratory symptoms without serious adverse events.
population_specificity: 236 patients diagnosed with lung cancer and major depressive disorder (MDD).
effective_dosage: Intranasal delivery once a week for 8 sessions (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine disparities in smoking cessation treatment between immigrants and U.S.-born individuals and identify barriers like insurance status and limited English proficiency.
results_summary: Immigrants had lower odds of being asked about tobacco use by healthcare providers compared to U.S.-born individuals. Uninsured immigrants and those with limited English proficiency were even less likely to receive smoking cessation advice or be asked about tobacco use.
population_specificity: 3,727 daily smokers (247 immigrants, 6.6%) from the 2018 and 2020 Medical Expenditure Panel Survey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective effect of autophagy against COPD and its specific mechanism using a mouse model.
results_summary: Rapamycin (RAPA) improved lung function, reduced pathological lung injury, and increased autophagy levels in COPD mice, while 3-methyladenine (3-MA) increased apoptosis. Autophagy stimulation may be a potential therapy for COPD.
population_specificity: Mouse model of COPD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of cytisinicline compared to placebo for smoking cessation and its effect on nicotine craving.
results_summary: Cytisinicline significantly improved smoking cessation rates compared to placebo, with higher abstinence rates at both 6- and 12-week treatments, and reduced nicotine craving. The treatment was well-tolerated with no serious adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults who smoked 10 or more cigarettes daily and sought to quit.
effective_dosage: 3 mg cytisinicline 3 times daily for 6 or 12 weeks.
study_duration: 6 or 12 weeks of treatment, with a 24-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the complex relationship between smoking and sarcoidosis, focusing on immune modulation, disease presentation, prognosis, and treatment response.
results_summary: The study found conflicting evidence on smoking's impact on sarcoidosis risk, severity, and treatment response, with some studies suggesting lower risk and others highlighting variations based on geography, ethnicity, and smoking history. Nicotine's dual pro- and anti-inflammatory properties further complicate its role in sarcoidosis.
population_specificity: Individuals with sarcoidosis or at risk of sarcoidosis, with variations based on geography and ethnicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand barriers and facilitators to accessibility at supervised smoking facilities (SSFs) from the perspectives of visitors and staff.
results_summary: The study identified key aspects of SSFs that improved accessibility, including non-punitive approaches, anonymity, peer involvement, and physical environment, while noting limitations like age restrictions and geographical location.
population_specificity: Peer workers and stakeholders at an SSF in Vancouver, Canada.
study_duration: Data collected between June 2021 and April 2022 (10 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of smoking among spontaneous pneumothorax patients in Syria and investigate its impact on recurrence rates.
results_summary: The study found that smoking was highly prevalent (80.13%) among spontaneous pneumothorax patients and significantly associated with recurrence (p=0.002). Male smokers had the highest recurrence rates, particularly with intercostal drainage treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with spontaneous pneumothorax treated at two university hospitals in Syria (156 patients: 135 males, 21 females).
study_duration: Data collected from January 2016 to January 2021 (5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the connection between affective temperaments, boredom proneness, and smoking behavior to inform smoking cessation interventions.
results_summary: Smokers exhibited higher cyclothymic temperament scores compared to non-smokers and ex-smokers, suggesting a link between this temperament and smoking. The study also found variable influences of specific temperaments on boredom proneness.
population_specificity: Italian population recruited via online survey (409 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how partner-involved financial incentive treatments could improve smoking cessation rates in dual-smoker couples by examining motivational and relationship mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that financial incentive treatments increased self-directed and partner-directed motivation, which mediated individual and joint abstinence outcomes. Partner-directed motivation specifically influenced joint abstinence at follow-up.
population_specificity: Dual-smoker couples (total n = 190)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to model the spread of addicted smoking and evaluate the effectiveness of parental guidance and anti-nicotine therapy in reducing smoking addiction.
results_summary: The study found that the transmission rate significantly contributes to the spread of addicted smoking, and both control strategies (parental guidance and anti-nicotine therapy) effectively reduced the number of addicted individuals. Optimal control paths minimized addiction rates within a specific time interval.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical model based on compartments like susceptible, addicted, and quitters).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine smoking couples' preferences for the format and content of couple-based smoking cessation interventions and partner support.
results_summary: The study found that smokers and their partners preferred interventions designed for both partners, interactive, and tailored, valuing positive support, open discussions, and partner involvement. Smokers preferred empathy, love, and trust from partners over information or advice.
population_specificity: 56 smoking couples (N=112 individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acceptability and appropriateness of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (distraction-themed) and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (acceptance-themed) smoking cessation messages among young adults who smoke.
results_summary: Overall, both distraction and acceptance messages received similar ratings, with no significant differences between them. Ratings varied by participant characteristics, with males, those with higher education, and those more motivated to quit giving more favorable ratings, while SGM individuals and daily smokers rated messages less favorably.
population_specificity: Diverse young adults who currently smoke tobacco cigarettes (N=301; Age M=26.6 years; 54.8% male; 51.5% racial/ethnic minority; 16.9% sexual or gender minority; 62.5% daily smokers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (CRT) under non-smoking conditions in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC).
results_summary: The study found that neoadjuvant CRT under non-smoking conditions, confirmed by exhaled CO levels <3 ppm, resulted in a 28.6% pathological complete response rate and favorable 5-year survival outcomes (78.0% recurrence-free, 85.7% overall survival). No significant survival differences were observed between smokers and non-smokers at diagnosis.
population_specificity: 28 patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC), median age 66, 71.4% male, 57.1% clinical stage III.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Treg-exo on lung function, inflammation, and immune response in a rat model of COPD induced by passive smoking combined with lipopolysaccharide.
results_summary: Treg-exo treatment improved lung function, reduced lung damage, decreased inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-8), and suppressed Th17 differentiation by inhibiting STAT3 phosphorylation.
population_specificity: Rats with COPD induced by passive smoking and lipopolysaccharide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map evidence for interventions, theories/models/frameworks (TMFs), and implementation strategies used in community-based smoking cessation programs.
results_summary: The study identified 12 discrete interventions, mostly multicomponent, with 19 distinct TMFs used in 26 out of 31 studies. Implementation strategies varied, with some studies incorporating culturally tailored approaches.
population_specificity: Community-based populations (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the generalizability of annotation methods developed for smoking cessation intervention reports to physical activity evidence and describe the steps in developing a second corpus for the Human Behaviour-Change Project.
results_summary: The study found that smoking cessation annotation methods were mostly transferable to physical activity but required adaptations for behavioral outcome codes. The paper outlines the process of adapting and applying these methods to a new corpus of physical activity interventions.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on intervention reports and expert consultation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prognosis of early-stage male HCC patients with chronic HBV infection who also had long-term smoking and drinking habits following local ablation treatment.
results_summary: The study identified monocytes and globulin as risk factors and pre-albumin (PALB) as protective for overall survival in HBV-induced male HCC patients with smoking and drinking habits, but did not directly assess the effects of smoking itself.
population_specificity: Early-stage male HCC patients with chronic HBV infection and long-term smoking and drinking habits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of smoking cessation programs on smoking abstinence rates and pregnancy outcomes in pregnant smokers.
results_summary: Cognitive-behavioral counseling and financial incentives significantly increased smoking abstinence rates and improved birth weights, while other behavioral approaches or pharmaceutical therapy showed no significant difference.
population_specificity: Pregnant smokers (8,149 participants across 21 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of smoking on the burden of laryngeal cancer in China from 1990 to 2021 and predict future trends up to 2035.
results_summary: The study found that smoking significantly increased the burden of laryngeal cancer in China, with rising deaths and DALYs, particularly among males, though age-standardized rates declined. Predictions indicate continued increases in absolute burden but declining standardized rates by 2035.
population_specificity: Chinese population, stratified by sex and age.
study_duration: Data analyzed from 1990 to 2021, with predictions up to 2035.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction between physical activity and smoking on the development of metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its components.
results_summary: The study found that smoking combined with low physical activity increased the odds of MetS and its components, while moderate/vigorous physical activity with smoking was associated with lower odds of some MetS components but higher odds of low HDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: 40,046 Iranian participants aged 25-64 years from the STEPS surveys (2007, 2011, and 2016).
interactions: Interaction with physical activity noted; no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of physical activity and urge coping on smoking cessation outcomes among women, comparing those who quit during the follicular menstrual phase versus standard care.
results_summary: Vigorous physical activity improved urge coping, which was associated with fewer cigarettes per day and greater likelihood of smoking abstinence. No significant differences were found between quitting during the follicular phase versus standard care.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women of reproductive age (average 33.4 years, smoking ~13.8 cigarettes/day at baseline).
study_duration: End of treatment (EOT) measured at 7-day abstinence; exact intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether smoking provides neuroprotective effects in cases of acute carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning by comparing neurocognitive outcomes between smokers and non-smokers.
results_summary: Initial analysis suggested smokers had lower rates of poor outcomes, but after controlling for confounders, no significant differences in neurocognitive outcomes were found between smokers and non-smokers at 1 month post-CO exposure. The study concluded that smoking status was not associated with more favorable neurocognitive outcomes.
population_specificity: 1150 patients with acute CO poisoning, divided into non-smoking (61.7%) and smoking (38.3%) groups.
study_duration: Neurocognitive outcomes assessed at 1 month post-CO exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test a tool (myCOtrak) for real-time monitoring of smoking behaviors in pregnant women to improve smoking cessation research.
results_summary: myCOtrak demonstrated high feasibility and usability, with 75% of participants continuing data submission for ≥14 days. It integrated real-time CO monitoring with self-reported smoking, NRT, and e-cigarette use, offering a scalable tool for smoking cessation research.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (23 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility of a remotely delivered, family-based financial incentive intervention for smoking cessation among Alaska Native and American Indian (ANAI) communities.
results_summary: Five out of 10 participants were abstinent at the final 6-month check-in, and two maintained abstinence throughout all check-ins. Most participants found the intervention helpful and would recommend it to others.
population_specificity: Alaska Native and American Indian (ANAI) adults who smoke and their chosen adult family members.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of virtual reality-based cue exposure therapy (VR-CET) versus progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) as add-ons to cognitive-behavioral group therapy (G-CBT) for smoking cessation.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in abstinence rates between VR-CET and PMR groups after six months (24% abstinent overall). Secondary outcomes showed reductions in craving and cigarette consumption and increased self-efficacy over time, regardless of intervention, but baseline craving negatively predicted abstinence in the VR-CET group.
population_specificity: Abstinence-motivated smokers (N=246).
effective_dosage: Six sessions of G-CBT plus four additional sessions of either VR-CET or PMR.
study_duration: Six months (with follow-ups at 1, 3, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between smoking cessation app (SCA) use initiation and the utilization of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), prescription medications, and quit attempts among adults who smoke.
results_summary: SCA use initiation was associated with increased odds of prescription medication utilization and quit attempts but not NRT utilization. The study suggests SCAs may serve as a useful population-level intervention for smoking cessation.
population_specificity: Adults who smoked at least 100 cigarettes in their lifetime, currently smoked every day or some days, and planned to quit within a year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess current practice pathways for smoking cessation screening and treatment in veterans with multiple sclerosis (VwMS) and explore potential sociodemographic disparities.
results_summary: The study found low rates of smoking cessation screening (58% eligible), limited interest in behavioral interventions (n=4), and few referrals to cessation clinics (n=2). Pharmacological interventions were more accepted (n=11), but disparities were noted for women and minoritized veterans.
population_specificity: Veterans with multiple sclerosis (VwMS) who were current or former smokers at a VA hospital in North Carolina.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nurse-initiated smoking cessation programs, focusing on counseling and education interventions.
results_summary: Nurse-initiated programs showed a significant short-term (6-month) improvement in quit rates (OR 1.43), but no significant difference was observed at 12 months (OR 1.18). Moderate heterogeneity was noted across studies.
population_specificity: Smokers participating in nurse-led cessation programs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the harmful effects of smoking on lower extremity arterial disease (LEAD) and emphasize the importance of smoking cessation interventions in medical management.
results_summary: Smoking is strongly associated with LEAD progression, worse post-procedural outcomes, and increased healthcare utilization due to mechanisms like endothelial dysfunction, oxidative stress, and inflammation. Smoking cessation is critical for LEAD patients, but interventions remain underutilized.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity arterial disease (LEAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of an Empowerment Theory-based smoking cessation intervention tailored for sexual and/or gender minoritized (SGM) individuals in high-stigma environments.
results_summary: The intervention showed promising feasibility (80% retention) and acceptability (81.3% recommendation rate), with 45.0% of participants reporting 7-day point prevalence abstinence at exit. Participants also reported improvements in psychological outcomes like assertiveness and reduced identity-related concerns.
population_specificity: Sexual and/or gender minoritized (SGM) adults in Oklahoma willing to quit smoking (N=20).
effective_dosage: Combination nicotine replacement therapy (NRT; patch and gum/lozenge) with behavioral support (specific dosages not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of smoking on shoulder arthroplasty outcomes, focusing on medical and surgical complications.
results_summary: The study found that smoking significantly increased the risk of readmission, revision, periprosthetic fracture, surgical site infection, and sepsis, but showed no significant differences in wound problems, thromboembolic events, renal complications, urinary tract infections, pulmonary complications, or myocardial infarctions.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing shoulder arthroplasty surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility of a smartphone app-based intervention combining Mindfulness Training for smoking cessation and Video Directly Observed Therapy for ART adherence among low-income PLWH.
results_summary: The study found that smoking abstinence rates doubled in the intervention groups (45.5% and 53.8%) compared to usual care (25.0%), and ART adherence improved by 53.0% in the intervention groups versus 30.7% in usual care. However, the app-based intervention had low feasibility due to technology access and language barriers, and the vDOT app was deemed unacceptable.
population_specificity: Low-income people living with HIV (PLWH), predominantly minority groups (53.8% males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore experts' views on facilitators and barriers to smoking cessation in Germany.
results_summary: Key facilitators included self-motivation, communication skills of intervention leaders, and knowledge about addiction mechanisms. Barriers included smokers' fears of quitting, environmental pressures, and inadequate counseling structures.
population_specificity: Health practitioners (medical doctors, psychologists, addiction therapists) in Germany.
study_duration: Interviews conducted from July to November 2022 (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether smoking significantly contributes to intraoperative blood loss in patients with metastatic spinal tumors and to investigate other potential risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that smoking was significantly associated with higher intraoperative blood loss and a greater incidence of massive blood loss, both before and after propensity score matching. Smokers were 2.268 to 3.764 times more likely to experience massive blood loss compared to non-smokers.
population_specificity: 252 patients with metastatic spinal disease undergoing posterior decompressive surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a qualitatively informed model of professionally led stop smoking outreach to engage people from deprived areas who were not using existing services.
results_summary: Professionally led outreach raised awareness, removed access barriers, and generated referrals, particularly when using a non-judgmental, person-centered approach combined with e-cigarette support. However, outreach was time-consuming and unpredictable, requiring effective community partnerships.
population_specificity: Staff from a Stop Smoking Service and community members from deprived areas in Central Bedfordshire, Bedford Borough, and Milton Keynes, England.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cigarette smoking extract (CSE) induces apoptosis and mitochondrial dysfunction in human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) via Sirt1-dependent mechanisms and its role in atherosclerosis.
results_summary: CSE reduced Sirt1 and SHH expression, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptosis in HUVECs. Overexpressing Sirt1 or activating the SHH pathway mitigated these effects, while inhibiting SHH signaling negated Sirt1's protective role. In vivo, cigarette smoke worsened atherosclerosis in ApoE-KO mice, downregulating Sirt1, SHH, and Gli1 while altering Bax and Bcl-2 expression.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and ApoE-KO mice.
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of CSE (specific amounts not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify challenges in implementing inpatient smoking cessation services and propose standardized recommendations to improve these services.
results_summary: The study found that inpatient smoking cessation services face challenges like low patient awareness and inconsistent staff engagement, and proposed four key recommendations to standardize and improve these services.
population_specificity: Inpatients at risk of chronic diseases due to smoking-related conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate smoking attitudes, self-reported practices, and COPD knowledge among Japanese adults to identify intervention targets for reducing smoking prevalence.
results_summary: The study found that gender (male) strongly predicts current smoking, higher smoking awareness reduces smoking likelihood (especially in older adults), and COPD awareness is linked to smoking only in the 20-29 age group. Despite willingness to quit (27.7%), few smokers (3.0%) were interested in cessation programs, and COPD knowledge was limited.
population_specificity: Japanese adults aged 20-59 years (537 participants categorized as smokers, former smokers, or non-smokers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a prognostic model to predict survival outcomes in non-smoking patients with lung adenocarcinoma using pathological and hematologic indicators.
results_summary: The study identified six significant variables (TNM stage, tumor size, WBC count, neutrophil percentage, lymphocyte percentage, and hemoglobin level) to build a predictive model with strong performance (C-index 0.786–0.811, AUC 0.771–0.860). High-risk groups showed significantly poorer prognosis than low-risk groups.
population_specificity: Non-smoking patients with lung adenocarcinoma (n=1,172, including 372 external validation cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether prenatal use of smoking cessation pharmacotherapies (NRT, varenicline, bupropion) was associated with increased risks of major congenital malformations (MCMs) compared to smoking during the first trimester.
results_summary: The study found no clear increased risk of MCMs overall with prenatal use of NRT or varenicline compared to smoking, though NRT was associated with a higher risk of digestive organ MCMs and varenicline with kidney/urinary tract MCMs. Bupropion data were too sparse for conclusive subgroup analysis.
population_specificity: Pregnant women who smoked during the first trimester or were dispensed smoking cessation pharmacotherapies 90 days before conception or during the first trimester, across four countries (Australia, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability of smart lighters among low-SES young adult smokers to assess their potential use in smoking cessation interventions.
results_summary: Sentiment toward smart lighters was mostly positive (54.36%), with facilitating conditions, performance expectancy, and effort expectancy being key acceptance factors. Concerns included privacy, lack of awareness, affordability, and potential unintended triggering of cravings.
population_specificity: Current cigarette smokers aged 18-29, not college-educated or enrolled in a 4-year college (low-SES indicator).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of the SmokeFree Buddy app on psychosocial determinants of smoking cessation, such as self-efficacy and support receipt.
results_summary: The intervention group showed higher daily self-efficacy and increased likelihood of support interactions post-quit date, but the quality and amount of support were lower compared to controls. No group differences were observed at the 6-month follow-up, and action control improved in both groups.
population_specificity: 162 adults intending to quit smoking.
study_duration: From 7 days before to 20 days after a self-set quit date, with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify brain-behavior models predicting smoking relapse vulnerabilities by examining associations between regulation of craving efficacy, neural circuitry, and smoking lapse.
results_summary: Worse regulation of craving efficacy predicted a greater hazard of smoking lapse. Resting-state neural circuitry, particularly frontal-striatal-limbic and sensory-motor connections, was associated with both regulation of craving efficacy and smoking lapse, with stronger functional connectivity linked to better outcomes.
population_specificity: Nicotine-dependent adult cigarette smokers (N = 213).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of smoking on acute and chronic toxicity in early breast cancer patients treated with hypofractionated IMRT and brachytherapy boost.
results_summary: Smoking significantly increased chronic fibrosis (35.6% vs. 24.7%) and chronic pain (7.9% vs. 3.3%) compared to nonsmokers, while acute toxicity was similar between groups. The study highlights smoking's detrimental effect on chronic toxicity despite advanced radiation techniques.
population_specificity: Early breast cancer patients treated with hypofractionated IMRT and brachytherapy boost (n=566, 31.3% smokers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the rates of misrepresentation of smoking status on the day of surgery in mixed elective surgical populations, comparing groups offered or not offered additional cessation support.
results_summary: The study found that 11.4% of participants achieved verified cessation before surgery, while 3.1% misrepresented quitting. Misrepresentation was higher in the intervention group (4.1%) than the control group (1.7%), and offering cessation help increased quitting odds by 77%.
population_specificity: Smokers (n=1413) undergoing elective surgery at a Melbourne public hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate two psychometric scales (SSM and ASAS) to measure smoking susceptibility and anti-smoking awareness in never-smoking youths.
results_summary: The study found that the SSM and ASAS scales were psychometrically valid, with smoking susceptibility inversely associated with school connectedness and positively associated with self-esteem, while anti-smoking awareness was positively linked to school connectedness.
population_specificity: Never-smoking youths (sample size n=312).

study_goal: To develop a cost-effective healthcare model for smoking management in Spain through expert consensus and literature review.
results_summary: The study established 11 general principles for smoking care, proposed two levels of care (non-specialized and specialized), and provided recommendations and care algorithms for smoking cessation.
population_specificity: Tobacco experts (3 pulmonologists, 3 primary care physicians, and 3 community pharmacists) and smokers in Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of the nuumi cessation program, which combines digital behavioral therapy and electronic cigarettes, in supporting smoking cessation and improving smoking-related outcomes among motivated adults.
results_summary: The program showed high self-reported abstinence rates (39.4% at 12 weeks, 32.4% at 24 weeks), significant reductions in cigarettes per day, decreased urges to smoke and perceived stress, and improvements in mindfulness, self-efficacy, life satisfaction, and subjective psychophysiological health, particularly among abstinent participants.
population_specificity: Adults who smoked and were motivated to quit.
effective_dosage: Pods containing decreasing nicotine concentrations (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the sex- and age-specific burden of bladder cancer attributable to smoking in China from 1990 to 2021 and predict future trends over the next 15 years.
results_summary: The study found that deaths and DALYs due to smoking-attributable bladder cancer significantly increased in China from 1990 to 2021, though ASMR and ASDR decreased, with males experiencing a higher burden. The decline was driven by population aging, and future projections indicate continued decreases in ASDR and ASMR by 2036, particularly among males.
population_specificity: Chinese population, stratified by sex and age groups.
study_duration: Data analyzed from 1990 to 2021, with projections to 2036.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and effectiveness of a smartphone app-based intervention combining social support and artificial intelligence to help pregnant smokers quit.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but the central hypothesis is that the intervention will increase social support, pregnancy cessation, and postnatal abstinence, with outcomes assessed at 6 months postpartum.
population_specificity: Pregnant smokers and their self-nominated supporters (300 participants total).
study_duration: Throughout pregnancy up to 1 month after birth, with follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a behavioral intervention could reduce smoking and associated biomarkers of nicotine and tobacco exposure in Black adults who smoke.
results_summary: The study found that while self-reported smoking reductions occurred in the enhanced care group, there were no significant decreases in biomarkers of nicotine and tobacco exposure. Compensatory behaviors or underreporting may explain the discrepancy.
population_specificity: Non-treatment-seeking, socioeconomically disadvantaged Black adults who smoke (N=65).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular mechanisms by which smoking exacerbates age-related macular degeneration (AMD) pathology, focusing on the role of the Sema4D-PlexinB1 axis.
results_summary: Smoking activates the Sema4D-PlexinB1 axis, leading to CD8+ T cell migration into choroidal neovascularization lesions, pericyte activation, and disrupted vascular homeostasis, promoting AMD progression. Inhibition of Sema4D reduced neovascularization and enhanced the effectiveness of anti-VEGF treatment.
population_specificity: Elderly population (implied by AMD focus) and mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the use, awareness, and preferences for smoking cessation support among individuals recently released from smoke-free prisons in Queensland, Australia.
results_summary: The study found that 32% of participants had used nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) or cessation medications before prison, while 26% used NRT in prison. Peer support groups were the most favored cessation method, and unsupported abstinence was slightly preferred over NRT post-release.
population_specificity: People recently released from smoke-free prisons in Queensland, Australia, who reported daily tobacco use upon prison entry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effects of cigarette smoking on the expression of m6A modification-regulating enzymes and the significance of m6A modification in biological responses to cigarette smoking.
results_summary: Cigarette smoke extract (CSE) decreased METTL3 and METTL14 protein levels in lung cells, and m6A modification influenced CYP1A1 induction by modulating ARNT and AHRR expression. Knockdown of METTL3 or ALKBH5 attenuated CYP1A1 mRNA induction, while FTO knockdown enhanced it.
population_specificity: Human lung adenocarcinoma-derived A549 cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess perceptions and intentions to use various smoking cessation approaches among American Indian persons.
results_summary: Participants viewed plant-based medications favorably due to their natural profile and cultural alignment, while concerns about effectiveness, side effects, and cost were noted for nicotine replacement therapy (NRT). Personalized medicine elicited curiosity but also skepticism, and cold turkey was seen as cost-effective but ineffective for cravings.
population_specificity: American Indian persons (N = 46)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between smoking status at baseline and 10-year outcomes (including mortality and cardiovascular events) in patients undergoing PCI with DES implantation.
results_summary: Smoking was associated with significantly higher risks of all-cause death, cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, and stent thrombosis over 10 years, but a lower risk of repeat revascularization. The risks were particularly pronounced for cardiovascular events beyond the first 30 days post-PCI.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES) implantation (n=9,527, with 2,365 smokers and 7,162 nonsmokers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the survival benefits of quitting smoking after a cancer diagnosis to inform patients.
results_summary: Quitting smoking around the time of cancer diagnosis improved 5-year overall survival, with greater gains in cancers with higher baseline survival rates (e.g., 10% gain in 90% survival scenarios vs. 2% in 20% survival scenarios). Median survival also increased by 2.1 years and 3 months, respectively.
population_specificity: Cancer patients in Japan (cohort study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of motivational interviewing on self-efficacy and addiction levels in nursing students attempting smoking cessation.
results_summary: The study found that motivational interviewing significantly increased self-efficacy and reduced nicotine addiction in the experimental group compared to the control groups, which showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Nursing students from two universities who smoked.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved face-to-face and online motivational interviews).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of mindfulness-based strategies and motivational messages delivered via a Just-in-Time Adaptive Intervention (JITAI) on proximal outcomes relevant to smoking abstinence.
results_summary: The JITAI significantly reduced negative affect in the final week of the intervention and led to significant decreases in perceived stress, automaticity of smoking, and craving, along with increased abstinence self-efficacy, which predicted abstinence.
population_specificity: 38 participants (63% female, 18% Hispanic or Latino, 29% African American), average age 49, smoking an average of 15 cigarettes per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how abstinence or reduced cigarette use during smoking cessation treatment affects smoking self-efficacy and whether assigned sex moderates this relationship.
results_summary: Abstinence was associated with higher increases in smoking self-efficacy across all facets, while reduced cigarette use was linked to increased total self-efficacy. AFAB smokers showed lower positive/social self-efficacy than AMAB smokers, but reducing cigarette use improved this aspect for AFAB smokers.
population_specificity: Smokers with depressive symptoms (n=146; 72.6% AFAB; mean age=46.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine sex, age, and menopause differences in nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)-aided smoking cessation outcomes in an all-Black sample.
results_summary: After adjusting for baseline differences in smoking rate, no significant sex differences in smoking cessation outcomes were observed. Males under 45 initially showed greater reduction in cigarettes/day, but this difference disappeared after adjustment.
population_specificity: Non-Hispanic Black adults aged 18+ who smoked 5-30 cigarettes/day for at least 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to pilot the FASTR tool with people with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) to identify necessary modifications for effective smoking cessation treatment personalization.
results_summary: The study found that the most frequently endorsed functions of smoking were Automatic Negative (87.5% of participants) and Social Negative (75% of participants). Participants recommended modifications like bolding key statement parts to improve inclusivity for people with IDD.
population_specificity: People with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) (n = 8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of inflammation (measured by CRP) on clozapine metabolism in smokers versus non-smokers.
results_summary: The study found a significant correlation between CRP levels and clozapine concentration in non-smokers but not in smokers, with non-smokers showing a 3-fold higher clozapine concentration at high CRP levels (>50 mg/L) compared to low CRP levels (<5 mg/L). No significant differences were observed in smokers across CRP groups.
population_specificity: 126 patients (47% smokers) from a therapeutic drug monitoring service in Oslo, Norway.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-adjusted serum concentration was analyzed).
study_duration: Retrospective data collected from January 2005 to April 2022.
interactions: Clozapine metabolism was influenced by inflammation (CRP levels) in non-smokers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize scientific evidence on how cigarette smoking alters the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of medications, including mechanisms and effects.
results_summary: The study found that smoking modifies the pharmacokinetics or effects of drugs in 31 out of 37 studies, often reducing plasma concentration or increasing drug clearance, particularly for psychiatric, neurological, and anticancer drugs, with CYP1A2 induction being a common mechanism.
population_specificity: Smoking subjects (healthy volunteers or patients) receiving any kind of medication.
interactions: Increased metabolism of psychiatric, neurological, anticancer, cardiovascular, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors, local anesthetics, and medications for musculoskeletal or chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in the profile of persons who smoke (PWS) seeking assistance from smoking cessation services (SCS) in France between 2004 and 2018, aligning with national policies.
results_summary: The study found that the mean age of SCS attendees increased, with higher proportions of PWS without a school diploma and unemployed individuals. Smoking-related cancer prevalence doubled, and fewer PWS attended SCS on personal initiative, while the mean number of cigarettes smoked daily remained stable.
population_specificity: Adult persons who smoke (PWS) seeking assistance from smoking cessation services in France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify genetic and immune regulatory mechanisms linking smoking to non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and explore potential driver genes.
results_summary: The study identified HLA-J and PRMT7 as core driver genes for smoking-associated NSCLC, with PRMT7 linked to cancer occurrence and HLA-J involved in immune evasion. Immune microenvironment analysis showed HLA-J enhances immune cell activity while PRMT7 suppresses it, facilitating tumor immune evasion.
population_specificity: Smokers with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and normal individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between smoking and tumor regression grade (TRG) in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC) receiving neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NACRT).
results_summary: Smoking was significantly associated with higher TRG, indicating poorer treatment efficacy, and was linked to lower overall survival (OS) in patients with LARC following NACRT. The hazard ratio for smoking was 2.32, showing a more than two-fold increased risk of higher TRG.
population_specificity: Patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC) who received neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NACRT) followed by surgical resection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mobile health (mHealth) profiling intervention, including nurse-led telephone counseling and instant messaging support, in increasing tobacco abstinence among individuals unwilling to use conventional smoking cessation aids.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly higher biochemically validated tobacco abstinence rates (8.2% vs. 3.5% at 3 months; 9.5% vs. 4.0% at 6 months) and greater improvements in Incremental Behavior Change Toward Smoking Cessation (IBC-S) scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 459 adults in Hong Kong with daily tobacco use, no recent use of smoking cessation services or medications, and no intention to use such aids in the next month.
effective_dosage: 5 ecological momentary assessments (EMAs) daily for 7 days, plus 10-week instant messaging support for the intervention group.
study_duration: 7 days of EMA, followed by 10 weeks of messaging support, with follow-ups at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether overexpression of the truncated IbTPS1 gene (△NIbTPS1) could improve sweet potato's tolerance to drought and salt stress by enhancing photosynthetic efficiency and antioxidative enzyme activity.
results_summary: Overexpression of △NIbTPS1 significantly improved stress tolerance in transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana and sweet potato, evidenced by higher germination rates, root elongation, fresh weight, photosynthetic efficiency, and antioxidative enzyme activity under drought and salt conditions, while reducing oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana and sweet potato plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the IbSAUR36 gene in sweet potato root development by analyzing its function in auxin signaling, lignin synthesis, and jasmonic acid (JA) signaling pathways.
results_summary: The study found that overexpression of IbSAUR36 promoted IAA accumulation, upregulated IAA synthesis and signaling genes, and downregulated lignin synthesis and JA signaling genes, indicating its role in adventitious root development. The gene was highly expressed in young tissues and responsive to phytohormones like IAA and MeJA.
population_specificity: Transgenic sweet potato roots (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the R2R3 MYB gene IbMYB330 in sweet potato's response to abiotic stresses like drought and salt.
results_summary: The study found that IbMYB330 enhances stress tolerance by increasing the expression of stress-related genes (SOD, POD, APX, P5CS) and improving biochemical markers (CAT activity, POD activity, proline content) while reducing MDA content in transgenic tobacco.
population_specificity: Transgenic tobacco plants (used as a model for sweet potato gene function).
study_duration: Not specified (stress treatments were applied, but exact duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the synergistic effects of poultry manure and wood biochar on the nutrient composition of sweet potato leaves and the mineral content in sweet potato storage roots.
results_summary: The study found that combining poultry manure (10.0 t ha-1) and biochar (30.0 t ha-1) significantly increased nutrient concentrations in sweet potato leaves and mineral content in storage roots, with notable synergistic effects and high economic profitability.
population_specificity: Sweet potato crops in southwestern Nigeria (Owo-site A and Obasooto-site B).
effective_dosage: Poultry manure at 0, 5.0, and 10.0 t ha-1; biochar at 0, 10.0, 20.0, and 30.0 t ha-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize KNOX genes in sweet potato and its diploid relatives, exploring their roles in growth, development, hormone response, and abiotic stress.
results_summary: The study identified 40 KNOX genes across sweet potato and its relatives, with specific genes (e.g., IbKNOX4, -5, -6) highly expressed in high-yield varieties and others (e.g., IbKNOX3, -8) upregulated in storage roots. KNOX genes were also involved in responses to abiotic stresses like PEG/mannitol and NaCl.
population_specificity: Sweet potato (I. batatas) and its diploid relatives (I. trifida, I. triloba).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hot air (HA) treatment at 45°C for 3 hours could mitigate chilling injury and maintain quality in sweet potato tuberous roots during cold storage.
results_summary: HA45°C-3h treatment delayed chilling injury and internal browning, preserved cellular structural integrity, reduced malondialdehyde accumulation and ion leakage, maintained osmoregulatory substances, and enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity and antioxidant substances compared to untreated sweet potatoes.
population_specificity: Sweet potato tuberous roots
study_duration: Duration of cold storage not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different water management treatments (hole irrigation, optimized drip irrigation, and traditional drip irrigation) on soil conditions, sweet potato growth, and yield.
results_summary: Drip irrigation (W2 and W3) maintained higher soil moisture and improved sweet potato survival rates, aboveground biomass, and yield compared to hole irrigation (W1). However, excessive drip irrigation (W3) led to imbalances in root development, while optimized drip irrigation (W2) showed better root morphology and lower deformity rates.
population_specificity: Sweet potato seedlings grown in northern China under field conditions.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (water management treatments, not a supplement dosage).
study_duration: 5 months (from planting on 18 May to harvest on 18 October 2021).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the Peleg model's suitability for modeling mass transfer during osmotic dehydration of sweet potato samples and determine equilibrium water and solid contents at various temperatures.
results_summary: The Peleg model accurately described water loss and solid gain dynamics during osmotic treatment, with high coefficients of determination (r² = 0.990–1.000). Effective moisture diffusivity ranged from 1.85 × 10⁻⁸ to 4.83 × 10⁻⁸ m²/s, and activation energy was between 7.096 and 16.652 kJ/mol.
population_specificity: Sweet potato variety samples (specific variety not mentioned).
effective_dosage: 80% sugar beet molasses solution, sample-to-solution ratio of 1:5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of saponin (SAP) and boron (B) could mitigate salinity stress in sweet potatoes by improving growth and physiological parameters.
results_summary: The study found that 0.15% SAP + 20 mg/L B significantly improved vine length, weight, root weight, chlorophyll content, photosynthetic rate, transpiration rate, and stomatal conductance in sweet potatoes under salinity stress compared to the control.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants subjected to salinity stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chemical composition and phenolic profile variations of sweet potato leaves during in vitro digestion, focusing on their bioaccessibility and bioactivity.
results_summary: The study found that Ecaishu No. 10 (EC10) exhibited better retention of phenolic compounds after drying and higher bioaccessibility of polyphenols during digestion, with enhanced bioactivities such as antioxidant capacity and enzyme inhibition.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective effects of purple sweet potato polysaccharide (PSPP) against concanavalin A-induced liver injury in mice, focusing on inflammation and oxidative stress pathways.
results_summary: PSPP significantly reduced liver damage, suppressed ALT and AST levels, and attenuated apoptosis in mice. It mitigated inflammation via the TLR4-P2X7R/NLRP3 pathway and reduced oxidative stress by activating the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway.
population_specificity: Mice and RAW264.7 cells (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dual modification (OSA and HMT) of sweet potato starch on the physicochemical and mechanical properties of starch films, particularly for use as sausage casings.
results_summary: The dual-modified sweet potato starch film (OSA@HMT-SPS) showed significantly reduced solubility, moisture content, water vapor permeability, and O2 permeability compared to unmodified SPS film, along with improved flexibility and elasticity. It also effectively mitigated lipid oxidation in sausages better than both unmodified SPS film and commercial collagen casings.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or material study, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary fermented sweet potato residue (FSPR) as a corn substitute on nutrient digestibility, meat quality, and intestinal microbes in yellow-feathered broilers.
results_summary: Fermented sweet potato residue (70% proportion) improved nutrient digestibility and protein content, while 8-10% FSPR supplementation enhanced slaughter performance, meat quality, and beneficial gut microbes in broilers. Higher FSPR levels also increased serum immunoglobulin levels and altered microbial diversity.
population_specificity: Yellow-feathered broilers (one-day-old chicks).
effective_dosage: 0%, 5%, 8%, and 10% FSPR as a substitute for corn in feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different cooking methods (steaming, deep-frying, baking) affect the phenolic content, antioxidant activity, and isomerization of caffeoylquinic acids in sweet potato.
results_summary: The study found that deep-frying increased antioxidant capacity over time, while heat treatment reduced major phenolic components (5-CQA and 3,5-diCQA) due to isomerization. Controlling cooking temperature and time could produce new bioactive compounds, suggesting potential for functional food development.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different varieties of purple sweet potato affect the structure, physical properties, and halochromic ability of shrimp freshness indicators.
results_summary: Different purple sweet potato varieties varied in starch, crude fiber, pectin, protein, fat, and anthocyanin content, influencing the indicators' microstructure, crystallinity, moisture, permeability, tensile strength, and color response. Six varieties were identified as suitable for indicating shrimp freshness.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on sweet potato varieties and their application in packaging).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how freezing pre-treatment at different temperatures and times affects the cellular structure of purple sweet potato and the quality of RFEP chips.
results_summary: Freezing once at -40°C improved puffing ratio (47.13% increase) and crispness (61.93% increase) while reducing hardness (23.44% decrease), with no significant impact on anthocyanin retention or color. Excessive freezing damaged cellular structure, but optimal conditions enhanced product quality.
population_specificity: Purple sweet potato samples subjected to RFEP processing.
effective_dosage: Not specified (freezing treatments: -20°C, -40°C, -80°C for 14 h, 1 or 2 times).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the economic feasibility of replacing maize and alfalfa hay with sweet potato vine (SPV) in rabbit diets.
results_summary: The study found that a 100% replacement of maize and alfalfa hay with SPV and banana peel reduced feed costs by 57% and increased the gain margin per animal by 32.55%, demonstrating economic viability.
population_specificity: Fifty New Zealand white rabbits weaned at 35 days of age.
effective_dosage: Increasing levels of SPV (T0, T25, T50, T75, T100% replacement of maize and alfalfa hay).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of light-yellow-fleshed sweet potatoes, focusing on their potential to suppress LPS-induced inflammation in RAW264.7 cells.
results_summary: The tuber extracts of light-yellow-fleshed sweet potatoes showed the highest suppression of LPS-induced IL-6 gene expression and production, attributed to activation of the Nrf2 oxidative stress response pathway. Hydrophobic components specific to the tuber were identified as the main active agents.
population_specificity: Mouse macrophage-like cell line RAW264.7 cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of humic and chitosan treatments on alleviating drought stress in sweet potatoes during critical growth phases and their impact on yield and water efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that early vine development is highly vulnerable to drought, reducing yield by 42.0%. Foliar humic application under full irrigation improved yield and water efficiency by 66.9% and 68.4%, respectively, while ground humic application outperformed foliar treatments under partial irrigation. The highest yield and efficiency were achieved with combined chitosan and humic ground applications.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants under controlled irrigation conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (humic and chitosan treatments applied via foliar spray or soil application, with tap water as control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how potassium fertilizer application affects lignin metabolism, root growth, storage root yield, and uniformity in sweet potato.
results_summary: Potassium application reduced lignin biosynthesis enzyme activities and lignin content, leading to increased storage root number, weight, and yield, with the K2 treatment (240 kg ha-1) showing the most significant improvements. The effect varied by sweet potato variety, with BJ553 responding earlier and more strongly than YS25.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants (varieties BJ553 and YS25) in field conditions.
study_duration: 2-year field experiments, with measurements taken at specific intervals (e.g., 10-30 days after planting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal late-season irrigation levels for sweet potatoes to improve yield and quality traits such as size, shape, color, and nutritional content.
results_summary: Late-season irrigation significantly increased yield and marketable yield, with T2 (75% ETc) and T3 (100% ETc) showing the highest yields and quality. Irrigation improved root shape, color vibrancy, and levels of carotenoids, vitamin C, and soluble sugar.
population_specificity: Sweet potatoes grown in northern China under varying irrigation conditions.
effective_dosage: Five irrigation levels (T0: unirrigated; T1: 33% ETc; T2: 75% ETc; T3: 100% ETc; T4: 125% ETc).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of heat treatment (35 °C for 24 h) on the quality characteristics and disease resistance of two sweet potato varieties against soft rot.
results_summary: Heat treatment inhibited Rhizopus stolonifer growth, reduced nutrient loss, improved structural characteristics and free radical scavenging capacity, and enhanced enzyme activities (APX, PPO, POD) while decreasing Cx and PG activities, thereby boosting disease resistance against soft rot.
population_specificity: Two sweet potato varieties (P32/P and Xinxiang).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of different shading levels on the growth profile, photosynthetic efficiency, and biochemical composition of leafy sweet potato.
results_summary: Shading reduced soluble sugar, starch, sucrose, and yield but increased chlorophyll content and improved light absorption efficiency. Moderate shading (30% and 50%) enhanced phenolic and flavonoid content, while transcriptome analysis revealed altered gene expression related to antioxidant activity, secondary metabolism, and photosynthesis under shading stress.
population_specificity: Leafy sweet potato plants under controlled shading conditions.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (shading levels: no shading, 30%, 50%, and 70%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how nitrogen (N) application rates and soil moisture levels affect early root growth and development in sweet potato cultivars, particularly focusing on vine overgrowth inhibition.
results_summary: The study found that high N and normal moisture (N2W2) inhibited root expansion and starch synthesis in the N-susceptible cultivar (J26), while the N-tolerant cultivar (X32) showed better root development under the same conditions. The interaction between N rates and water regimes significantly influenced root morphology and vascular structure in J26 but had minimal impact on X32.
population_specificity: Sweet potato cultivars Jishu26 (N-susceptible) and Xushu32 (N-tolerant) in a pot experiment.
effective_dosage: Nitrogen application rates of 50 (N1) and 150 mg kg-1 (N2); water regimes of drought stress (W1) and normal moisture (W2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different planting densities affect sweet potato storage root formation, yield, and commercial characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that an appropriate planting density (D20) enhanced carbohydrate accumulation, reduced lignin biosynthesis, increased storage root number and yield (10.18-19.73% higher than control), and improved commercial features like root weight uniformity and length/diameter ratio.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants in field experiments across two sites over two years.
effective_dosage: Four planting densities (D15, D20, D25, D30) – exact spacing not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether sweet potato vines (SPV) could effectively replace maize and alfalfa hay in rabbit diets without compromising performance, meat quality, or economic feasibility.
results_summary: The study found that replacing maize and alfalfa hay with SPV and banana peels up to 100% did not negatively affect feed intake, weight gain, feed conversion, meat composition, or color in rabbits, while significantly reducing feed costs.
population_specificity: New Zealand White rabbits weaned at 35 days with an average body mass of ± 614 g.
effective_dosage: 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% replacement of maize and alfalfa hay with SPV and banana peels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how temperature changes during heat-moisture treatment (HMT) affect the appearance, structure, and digestibility of sweet potato starch (SPS).
results_summary: HMT caused surface depressions, cavities, and fragments on SPS particles, reduced crystallinity and short-range order, and increased thermal stability. The resistant starch content peaked at 24.77% after 4 hours of treatment at 110°C and 25% moisture.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on sweet potato starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether preheating whey protein concentrate (WPC) could improve the stability and antioxidant activity of purple sweet potato anthocyanins (ANs).
results_summary: The study found that preheating WPC significantly improved the retention and stability of ANs under various conditions (heat, light, UV, and oxidative stress) and enhanced their antioxidant activity in simulated digestive juice. The interaction between WPC and ANs was identified as a non-covalent, hydrophobic binding at one site.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the compounds in sweet potato responsible for its anti-diabetic activity and the mechanisms by which they act.
results_summary: The study identified four sweet potato varieties with anti-diabetic properties, attributing their effects to phenolic acids, flavonols, flavanones, and anthocyanidins. The anti-diabetic mechanism involves multi-target actions, supporting sweet potato's effectiveness in treating type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dual regulatory effects and molecular mechanisms of diacylated anthocyanins from purple sweet potato on hyperglycemia and hyperuricemia induced by a high-fructose/high-fat diet.
results_summary: Diacylated AF-PSPs alleviated hyperuricemia and hyperglycemia in mice by regulating liver XO activity, reducing lipid accumulation, improving insulin sensitivity, and lowering kidney injury and inflammation. The study also found improvements in liver oxidative stress and renal fructose metabolism.
