population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fructose/high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the IbHAK11 gene in sweet potatoes in regulating potassium (K+) uptake and translocation under low K+ and high salinity stress conditions.
results_summary: The study found that IbHAK11 overexpression enhanced root growth under low K+ conditions, improved growth and photosynthetic characteristics under high salinity stress, and activated ROS scavenging systems, leading to lower oxidative stress markers. It also promoted K+ translocation and reduced Na+ absorption, maintaining K+/Na+ homeostasis.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis plants (transgenic and wild-type) under low K+ and high salinity stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize ACTIN genes in sweet potato and its diploid relatives to understand their roles in plant growth, tuberous root development, and stress responses.
results_summary: The study identified 113 ACTIN genes across sweet potato and its relatives, classifying them into six subgroups. These genes were found to play vital roles in growth, development, and stress responses, with some identified as stable internal reference genes for qRT-PCR.
population_specificity: Cultivated hexaploid sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas) and its diploid relatives (Ipomoea trifida and Ipomoea triloba).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purple sweet potato (PSP) powder could mitigate high-fat diet-induced dry eye disease (DED) by regulating oxidative stress and lipid homeostasis.
results_summary: PSP treatment preserved lacrimal gland secretory function, prevented ocular surface erosion, reduced oxidative stress, and regulated lipid homeostasis, though it did not significantly reduce body weight or fat.
population_specificity: Animal model (high-fat diet-induced DED)
effective_dosage: 5% PSP powder added to the diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of purple sweet potato anthocyanins (PSPA) on growth performance, oxidative status, immune response, intestinal morphology, and intestinal flora homeostasis in heat-stressed Wenchang chickens.
results_summary: PSPA reversed adverse effects of heat stress on growth performance, meat quality, and carcass characteristics, improved antioxidant status, regulated inflammatory cytokines, enhanced intestinal morphology, and altered microbial composition. The effects were dose-dependent, with higher doses showing more pronounced benefits.
population_specificity: 50-day-old Wenchang chickens exposed to heat stress (33°C ± 1°C).
effective_dosage: 8 mg/kg (low dose), 16 mg/kg (medium dose), and 32 mg/kg (high dose) body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how steaming treatment affects the soluble dietary fiber (SDF) content and probiotic properties of sweet potato.
results_summary: Steaming sweet potato for 20 minutes increased SDF content and altered its composition, but the resulting SDF had inferior probiotic properties compared to fresh sweet potato SDF, as evidenced by lower production of beneficial acids during fermentation.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Lactobacillus spp.
study_duration: 20 minutes of steaming, 24 hours of fermentation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of pulsed electric fields (PEF) and blanching pretreatments on frying kinetics, oil content, color, texture, acrylamide content, and microstructure of sweet potato chips.
results_summary: Pretreatment significantly reduced moisture ratio and oil content by 25% and 40.33%, respectively, lowered total color change, increased hardness after frying, and reduced acrylamide content by 46.10% in PEF + blanching samples. The combined pretreatment also resulted in a smoother and flatter microstructure.
population_specificity: Sweet potato chips (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: PEF pretreatment: 0.2 s at 1 kV/cm; blanching: 85 °C for 5 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of anthocyanin-containing purple sweet potato synbiotic yogurt (PSPY) on 3T3-L1 adipocyte differentiation and its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: PSPY significantly suppressed adipogenic gene expression (Pparg, Adipoq, Slc2a4, Pgc1a) and lipid accumulation, with stronger effects than plain yogurt, suggesting potential for obesity management.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 preadipocyte cell line
study_duration: From 24 hours after seeding until day 11 of differentiation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quality characteristics of jelly made from saccharified sweet potatoes across three different cultivars (Juwhangmi, Sinjami, and Daeyumi).
results_summary: The study found that enzyme treatment increased free sugar and glucose content in the hydrolysate, but no differences in moisture, soluble solids, or texture were observed among cultivars. Sinjami had the highest polyphenol, flavonoid, and antioxidant activity, while Daeyumi was the most preferred in sensory evaluation.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on sweet potato cultivars, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the toxicity of lutein-rich purple sweet potato leaf (PSPL) extract in male Sprague-Dawley rats.
results_summary: The study found no signs of toxicity in rats treated with PSPL extract, as evidenced by normal body weight, blood biochemistry, hematological parameters, organ weight, and histological sections across all tested dosages up to 2,000 mg/kg/day.
population_specificity: Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats.
study_duration: Acute study: 14 days; subacute study: 28 days with an additional 14-day observation period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of white-skinned sweet potato (WSSP) on blood glucose homeostasis and the underlying mechanisms in normal rats.
results_summary: WSSP administration acutely reduced blood glucose levels by improving insulin sensitivity in skeletal muscles (attributed to ≤10 kDa constituents) and suppressed liver gluconeogenesis (attributed to >50 kDa constituents). Serum insulin levels were unaffected.
population_specificity: Normal rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of DCAP-coated phosphorus fertilizer on phosphorus availability, nutrient uptake, and yield of sweet potato in acidic soils.
results_summary: DCAP-coated P fertilizer significantly improved phosphorus availability (~3 mg P kg-1) and increased sweet potato tuber diameter and length. Field experiments showed that DCAP combined with 75% P fertilizer achieved similar P availability and yield as 100% P fertilizer, reducing chemical P fertilizer use by ~25%.
population_specificity: Sweet potato cultivated in acid sulfate soils under greenhouse and field conditions.
effective_dosage: 40-kg P2O5 ha-1 and 60-kg P2O5 ha-1 (coated and uncoated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and analyze the two-component system (TCS) genes in sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas) and investigate their roles in growth, development, and response to environmental stresses.
results_summary: The study identified 90 TCS genes in sweet potato, mapped their distribution, and analyzed their expression profiles in different organs and under abiotic stresses. Most TCS genes showed organ-specific expression and responded to environmental stresses and phytohormone ABA, with protein-protein interactions revealed via yeast-two hybrid assays.
population_specificity: Sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas) genome and gene expression profiles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the XTH gene family in sweet potato (I. batatas) and analyze their expression patterns in different tissues and under stress conditions.
results_summary: The study identified 36 XTH genes in sweet potato, which were divided into three subfamilies and showed differential expression in various tissues, particularly roots. Some genes were up-regulated under salicylic acid treatment but down-regulated under methyl jasmonate, while only two genes showed down-regulation under cold and drought stress.
population_specificity: Sweet potato (I. batatas) plant tissues (leaves, stems, roots, etc.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sweet-potato-vine-based porous carbon (SPVPC) as an adsorbent for removing methylene blue from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The optimized SPVPC demonstrated a high specific surface area (1397.8 m² g⁻¹) and excellent adsorption capacity for methylene blue (653.6 mg g⁻¹), with good reusability. The adsorption process followed pseudo-second-order kinetics and the Langmuir isotherm model, indicating efficient dye removal.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on aqueous solutions).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (adsorption capacity measured in mg g⁻¹).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of long-term soil drought on sucrose-starch metabolism in sweet potato tuberous roots (TRs) across different drought levels.
results_summary: Drought stress increased soluble sugar and sucrose content but reduced starch accumulation in sweet potato TRs by inhibiting key enzyme activities (AI, AKI, AGPase, GBSS, SBE) and altering gene expressions (IbA-INV3, IbSWEET11, IbSWEET605, IbSUT4). The sucrose-loading capability varied among cultivars, with Jishu 26 showing stronger responses than Xushu 32 and Ningzishu 1.
population_specificity: Sweet potato tuberous roots (TRs) of cultivars Jishu 26, Xushu 32, and Ningzishu 1.
effective_dosage: Soil-relative water content (SRWC) levels: (75 ± 5)% (control), (55 ± 5)% (mild drought), (45 ± 5)% (severe drought).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of culture medium, plant growth regulators, and artificial light sources on the micropropagation of Jewel sweet potato shoots.
results_summary: The study found that a medium with 50% MS salt concentration supplemented with 0.5 mg/L BAP or 0.5 mg/L Kn combined with 0.5 mg/L IAA was optimal for shoot induction, proliferation, and growth. Different blue/red light ratios also significantly influenced explant growth and shoot or root formation.
population_specificity: In vitro Jewel sweet potato shoots (axillary bud and shoot tip explants).
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg/L IAA combined with 0.5-2.0 mg/L BAP, 0.5-2.0 mg/L Kn, or 0.1-1.0 mg/L TDZ.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize SWEET family genes in sweet potato and its diploid relatives to understand their roles in plant growth, development, and stress responses.
results_summary: The study identified 27, 27, and 25 SWEET genes in cultivated sweet potato and its two diploid relatives, respectively, and found they play vital roles in growth, tuber development, carotenoid accumulation, and stress response.
population_specificity: Cultivated hexaploid sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas) and its diploid relatives (Ipomoea trifida and Ipomoea triloba).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of varying vanadium concentrations on sweet potato growth, physiology, and biochemical mechanisms.
results_summary: Low vanadium (10 mg L-1) enhanced sweet potato growth and biomass, while higher concentrations (25, 50, and 75 mg L-1) negatively impacted root growth, photosynthesis, stomatal traits, and antioxidant defense systems. Vanadium accumulation was higher in roots than shoots, and oxidative stress markers increased under higher vanadium exposure.
population_specificity: Hydroponically grown sweet potato plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the production of starch nanoparticles (SNPs) from sweet potato starches and evaluate the effects of cold plasma treatment on inhibiting aggregation during freeze-drying.
results_summary: The study successfully produced SNPs with a Z-average size of 64.51 nm and found that cold plasma treatment significantly reduced aggregation during freeze-drying. SNPs exhibited higher relative crystallinity and lower apparent viscosity compared to native starch, with further improvements after cold plasma treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel enzymes from Penicillium sclerotigenum for selective modification of sweet potato pectin to valorize processing residues.
results_summary: The study confirmed a rhamnogalacturonan I-rich pectin fraction in sweet potato and identified 23 pectin-associated degradative enzymes from P. sclerotigenum, including six potentially novel enzymes. The findings suggest potential for improved sweet potato pectin modification and residue valorization.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how pullulanase debranching combined with autoclaving affects the structural and physicochemical properties of purple sweet potato starch, particularly its resistant starch yield.
results_summary: The study found that debranching and autoclaving altered the starch's structure, increasing crystallinity and resistant starch yield, with the optimal combination being 15 hours of debranching and 20 minutes of autoclaving at 121°C.
population_specificity: Purple sweet potato (Jinshu No.17) starch
effective_dosage: Not specified (various debranching times: 0 h, 5 h, 10 h, 15 h, 20 h, 25 h; autoclaving at 121°C for 20 min)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxic effects of chromium (Cr) on sweet potato plants, focusing on growth, physiological parameters, and oxidative damage under varying Cr concentrations.
results_summary: Low Cr levels (25 µM) enhanced growth, biomass, photosynthesis, and antioxidant activity, while higher Cr levels (200 µM) caused significant oxidative damage, reduced photosynthetic rates, and structural damage to chloroplasts. Osmolytes and SOD activity increased with Cr concentration but were insufficient to protect against high Cr stress.
population_specificity: Hydroponically grown sweet potato plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the structural characteristics of a novel polysaccharide (PSPP-A) from purple sweet potato and its preventive effects on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that PSPP-A significantly reduced body weight, liver index, and markers of liver damage (TG, TC, AST, ALT) in a high-fat diet group, while also improving liver histopathology by reducing irregular hepatocyte patterns and lipid vacuoles.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal model implied by high-fat diet intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of biochar and potassium fertilizer, both individually and in combination, on soil properties and sweet potato growth and yield.
results_summary: The study found that biochar alone or combined with potassium fertilizer improved soil properties and sweet potato growth and yield compared to control or potassium fertilizer alone. The combination of 20 t ha-1 biochar + 70 kg ha-1 K fertilizer was recommended as optimal for sweet potato production.
population_specificity: Sweet potato crops in experimental agricultural settings (specific geographic or demographic details not provided).
effective_dosage: Biochar: 0, 10, 20 t ha-1; Potassium fertilizer: 0, 70, 120 kg ha-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the roles of bHLH transcription factors (IbbHLH118 and IbbHLH66) in the ABA-mediated drought response in sweet potato.
results_summary: The study found that IbbHLH118 reduces drought tolerance by suppressing ABA-responsive genes, while IbbHLH66 enhances drought tolerance by activating ABA responses. ABA promotes the formation of a complex (IbPYL8-IbbHLH66-IbbHLH118) that interferes with IbbHLH118's repression, thereby improving drought tolerance.
population_specificity: Drought-tolerant sweet potato line Xushu55-2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify transcriptional changes in sweet potato roots under potassium (K+) deficiency to understand its molecular response to low-K+ stress.
results_summary: The study identified 559 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in sweet potato roots under low-K+ conditions, with 336 upregulated and 223 downregulated. These DEGs were linked to transcriptional regulation, hormone signaling, and stress response, suggesting key roles in K+ deficiency tolerance.
population_specificity: Sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas L.) seedlings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of sweet potato IbCCD4 in salt stress tolerance by analyzing its expression and effects in Arabidopsis under salt and dehydration stress.
results_summary: The study found that IbCCD4 overexpression in Arabidopsis increased anthocyanins and carotenoid content under salt stress but reduced salt tolerance by decreasing resistance-related gene expression and antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (model plant)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-glioma effects of purple sweet potato delphinidin-3-rutin (PSPD3R) and its molecular mechanism in autophagy regulation.
results_summary: PSPD3R suppressed glioma proliferation in vitro and in vivo, stimulated autophagy and apoptosis in glioma cells, and regulated autophagy via the Akt/Creb/miR-20b-5p/Atg7 axis. The study demonstrated PSPD3R's potential as a therapeutic agent for glioma treatment.
population_specificity: Human glioblastoma (GBM) cells (U251) and a subcutaneous xenograft model of GBM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and analyze nifH genes in sweet potatoes and their wild ancestors to understand their role in nitrogen fixation and potential contributions to molecular breeding.
results_summary: The study identified 20, 19, and 17 nifH genes in sweet potatoes, I. trifida, and I. triloba, respectively, with phylogenetic clustering into five clades. Four selected nifH genes in sweet potatoes were upregulated under normal nitrogen conditions, consistent with RNA-seq data.
population_specificity: Sweet potato cultivars (Eshu 15 and Long 9) and their wild ancestors (I. trifida and I. triloba).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether purple sweet potato color (PSPC) could ameliorate dysregulation in the ovary, brain, and liver in a mouse model of Classic Galactosemia.
results_summary: PSPC supplementation showed positive effects in reducing dysregulation in the ovary, brain, and liver of mutant mice, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for Classic Galactosemia complications.
population_specificity: GalT gene-trapped mouse model (Classic Galactosemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the function of the MYB transcription factor gene IbMYB308 in sweet potato, particularly its role in improving salt stress tolerance.
results_summary: The study found that IbMYB308 is a typical R2R3-MYB transcription factor expressed in root, stem, and leaf tissues, with induced expression under abiotic stresses. Transgenic tobacco with IbMYB308 showed improved salt stress tolerance, evidenced by upregulated stress-related genes and altered biochemical markers.
population_specificity: Transgenic tobacco plants (used as a model for sweet potato gene function).
effective_dosage: Not specified (stress treatments: 20% PEG-6000, 200 mM NaCl, and 20% H2O2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of thermochemical pre-treatment on biogas and methane production from sweet potato root waste (SPW) through anaerobic digestion.
results_summary: Thermochemical pre-treatment of SPW significantly improved biogas yield (33.88% increase) and methane content (22% increase) while reducing digester retention time from 22 to 16 days. Optimal conditions were a NaOH concentration of 2.9 g/L, heating temperature of 82 °C, and pre-treatment time of 102 min.
population_specificity: Agricultural waste (sweet potato root waste)
effective_dosage: NaOH concentration (0.6 g/L-3.5 g/L), temperature (50 °C-90 °C), pre-treatment time (30-120 min)
study_duration: Pre-treatment time up to 120 min, digester retention time reduced to 16 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which IbMPK3-overexpressing transgenic sweet potato plants confer low-temperature stress tolerance compared to wild-type plants.
results_summary: The study identified differentially expressed genes (DEGs) related to low-temperature stress in both wild-type and transgenic plants, revealing involvement in Ca2+ signaling, MAPK cascades, ROS signaling, hormone transduction, and stress-related transcription factors. Transgenic plants showed more upregulated genes in MAPK pathways during short-term stress and in secondary metabolic synthesis during long-term stress.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants (wild-type and IbMPK3-overexpressing transgenic).
study_duration: Low-temperature stress exposure for 2 hours and 12 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the selenium tolerance of sweet potato cultivars and its effects on plant growth, physiological activities, and selenium content distribution.
results_summary: The study found that selenium concentrations above 3 mg/L significantly affected plant growth, while 1 mg/L increased chlorophyll content. Selenium content in roots was higher than in stems and leaves, with the optimal tolerance concentration determined as 3 mg/L.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants (Dioscorea esculenta) grown in a greenhouse.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of green and purple sweet potato leaf (SPL) supplementation on hepatic xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes, oxidative stress, and benzo[a]pyrene (B[a]P) metabolism and accumulation in rats.
results_summary: Green and purple SPL increased hepatic enzyme activity, reduced oxidative stress, and enhanced xenobiotic detoxification. Green SPL specifically improved B[a]P metabolism, lowered B[a]P levels in tissues, and reduced oxidative damage markers.
population_specificity: Rats (standard and B[a]P-treated models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purple sweet potato water extract could act as an antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent to prevent neuronal apoptosis and provide neuroprotective effects in d-galactose-induced rats.
results_summary: The study found that purple sweet potato extract significantly reduced TNF-α levels, p53 and GFAP expressions, increased BDNF levels, and improved spatial working memory compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats induced with d-galactose.
study_duration: 70 days (extract administered on days 1-70, d-galactose induction on days 15-70).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of the sweet potato cultivar Simon 1 (SIMON) on chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia (CIT) in mice.
results_summary: SIMON significantly increased peripheral platelets, white blood cells, and bone marrow nucleated cells in CIT mice, reversed carboplatin-induced atrophy of the thymus and spleen, and improved inflammatory immune system and glycerophospholipid metabolism. Phytochemical analysis identified 16 compounds, including phenolic derivatives, potentially linked to its anti-CIT bioactivity.
population_specificity: Chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia (CIT) mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the molecular mechanisms of flooding resistance in sweet potato cultivars, focusing on ethylene, reactive oxygen species, and nitric oxide regulation.
results_summary: The study found that flood-tolerant sweet potato cultivars exhibited upregulated expression of genes related to low oxygen signaling, ROS scavenging, and NO biosynthesis, compared to flood-sensitive cultivars. These mechanisms appear crucial for sweet potato's response to flooding stress.
population_specificity: Two sweet potato cultivars (one flood-tolerant, one flood-sensitive) under early flooding treatment conditions.
study_duration: Early flooding treatment (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of microwave alone (MA) and microwave-assisted L-malic acid (MLA) on the physicochemical properties, structure, and digestibility of sweet potato starch.
results_summary: MLA treatment reduced swelling power, lightness, whiteness index, and gelatinization enthalpy while increasing resistant starch (RS) content, whereas MA treatment reduced RS content. MLA-modified starch showed structural changes, including a new FT-IR absorption peak, and was deemed suitable as a low-carbohydrate food ingredient, while MA-treated starch was better for low-swelling foods like noodles.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on sweet potato starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how larval diet (sweet potato powder vs. sweet potato tubers) affects reproductive traits, specifically the refractory period and ejaculate composition, in adult male West Indian sweet potato weevils.
results_summary: The study found that the refractory period was significantly longer in weevils reared on sweet potato tubers compared to those on artificial diet, with no difference in ejaculate volume but higher sperm count and a unique 15 kDa protein in the tuber-reared group.
population_specificity: West Indian sweet potato weevils (Euscepes postfasciatus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purple sweet potato anthocyanin extract (PSPAE) could improve obesity and redox state in mice fed a high-fat/cholesterol diet.
results_summary: High-dose PSPAE significantly reduced body weight, serum cholesterol, and triglycerides while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activities and improving gut microbiota composition. It also suppressed inflammatory markers and preserved intestinal barrier function.
population_specificity: Obese mice fed a high-fat/cholesterol diet.
effective_dosage: Low, middle, and high doses (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize calcium-dependent protein kinases (CDPKs) in sweet potato and its diploid relatives to explore their roles in growth, development, and abiotic stress responses.
results_summary: The study identified 39 CDPKs in hexaploid sweet potato and 35 each in its diploid relatives, revealing tissue-specific expression patterns and evolutionary differences. These findings provide candidate genes for improving yield and stress tolerance in cultivated sweet potato.
population_specificity: Cultivated hexaploid sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas) and its diploid relatives (Ipomoea trifida and Ipomoea triloba).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability of a shelf-stable MDCF-2 formulation containing sweet potato compared to the original kitchen-prepared version.
results_summary: The sweet potato MDCF-2 formulation achieved high acceptability scores (86.2 ± 4.26 g consumed) and was comparable to the kitchen-prepared version, with no significant differences in consumption rates.
population_specificity: Bangladeshi children aged 8 to 12 months living in an urban slum in Dhaka.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the drying performance of sweet potato slices using a hot-air oven dryer and a naturally-ventilated solar-venturi dryer, and to identify the best mathematical model for predicting moisture ratio.
results_summary: The study found that the drying rate was higher in the hot-air oven dryer, but the naturally-ventilated solar-venturi dryer with lemon juice pre-treatment was suitable for small-medium scale drying. The Midilli et al. model best predicted moisture ratio, and drying time was significantly affected by slice thickness.
population_specificity: Sweet potato tubers sliced at 3, 5, and 7 mm thicknesses under Pietermaritzburg conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of orange-fleshed sweet potato (OFSP) in addressing vitamin A deficiency in South Africa and identify opportunities for scaling its consumption and commercial production.
results_summary: The study found that 66g of the OFSP variety Bophelo can meet the daily vitamin A requirement for children aged 1-3 years, highlighting its potential to combat vitamin A deficiency. However, current consumption is low, and scaling efforts face challenges in market access and processing opportunities.
population_specificity: Children under 5 years of age in South Africa, particularly those with vitamin A deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate potential associations between synbiotic consumption and reduced risk of diabetic kidney disease (DKD) in adults with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found an independent association between synbiotic intake and reduced risk of DKD (OR = 0.71, 95% CI: 0.52-0.96, P = 0.03), though subgroup analysis indicated inconsistencies in correlations.
population_specificity: Adults with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2007-2016.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of four formulated synbiotics on gut microbiota composition and related biomarkers in Colombian children with and without autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The synbiotics decreased the abundance of certain genera (e.g., Bacteroides, Dorea) in ASD-associated samples while increasing probiotic-related genera (e.g., Lactobacillus, Streptococcus, Anaerostipes). They also elevated butyric acid and microbial serotonin synthesis while reducing propionic acid, suggesting beneficial modulation of gut microbiota in ASD.
population_specificity: Colombian children with and without ASD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prebiotic and synbiotic interventions could mitigate radiotherapy-induced gut injury by modulating microbiota, reducing inflammation, and enhancing gut barrier function in rectal cancer patients.
results_summary: The synbiotic group showed reduced inflammation and fibrosis compared to controls, preserved more bacterial diversity post-radiotherapy, and exhibited a significant reduction in white blood cell counts, though systemic inflammation effects were limited due to short-term treatment.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with rectal adenocarcinoma scheduled for preoperative short-term radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Oat bran with L. plantarum HEAL19 and blueberry husks, administered daily.
study_duration: Two weeks (starting one week before radiotherapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the roles and applications of probiotics, including synbiotics, in enhancing host health through microbial interactions and their potential therapeutic benefits.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics enhance the survivability and beneficial effects of probiotics, improve immunity, support growth, prevent diseases, and may treat gastrointestinal disorders by modulating gut microbiota and producing beneficial secondary metabolites.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health and potential applications in endangered wildlife species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the gastrointestinal tolerance, adhesion properties, and anti-allergic effects of specific Lactobacillus strains combined with oligosaccharides, particularly focusing on Lp-FOS.
results_summary: Lp-FOS demonstrated strong resistance to gastrointestinal conditions, promoted Lactobacillus proliferation, increased short-chain fatty acid production, and modulated immune responses by upregulating Th1 and Tregs while downregulating Th2 and Th17 cells and suppressing pro-inflammatory cytokines.
population_specificity: In vitro models (BMDCs, splenocytes, Caco-2 cells)

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of perioperative probiotics or synbiotics on the incidence of postoperative infections following major liver surgery.
results_summary: Perioperative probiotics or synbiotics significantly reduced postoperative infection incidence and antibiotic therapy duration, but no significant differences were observed in ICU or hospital length of stay.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major liver surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a synbiotic could alleviate hyperphosphatemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT) in a cisplatin-induced CKD rat model.
results_summary: The synbiotic reduced serum phosphate, calcium-phosphorus product, parathyroid hormone, and indoxyl sulfate levels, while increasing type 1 RNA and protein expression, suggesting improved gut barrier function and suppressed phosphate transport.
population_specificity: Cisplatin-induced chronic kidney disease (CKD) rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of synbiotics (composed of d-tagatose and probiotics) in treating oxidative stress and immune response in Gallus gallus caused by aflatoxin b1.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics significantly reduced oxidative stress and immune response markers in Gallus gallus, upregulated beneficial gut bacteria, and increased antioxidant and anti-inflammatory metabolites.
population_specificity: Gallus gallus (chickens) exhibiting oxidative stress and immune response due to aflatoxin b1 exposure.
effective_dosage: Not specified (low-dose treatment group mentioned, but exact dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of probiotics or synbiotics in preventing and treating diarrhea, reducing mortality, and shortening ICU stays among critically ill patients.
results_summary: Probiotics slightly reduced diarrhea incidence by 10%, but the result was not statistically significant. No significant effects were found on diarrhea duration, ICU stay length, or mortality.
population_specificity: Intensive Care Unit (ICU) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synbiotic supplementation (Bifidobacterium breve M-16V, scGOS, and lcFOS) accelerates gut microbiota recovery in toddlers after antibiotic treatment.
results_summary: The study compares gut microbiota recovery (Bifidobacterium proportion, species composition, and beta diversity) between synbiotic-treated and control groups, alongside metabolic activity and stool characteristics, but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Dutch toddlers aged 12-36 months receiving amoxicillin or amoxicillin/clavulanic acid treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of probiotics, prebiotics, and synbiotics in improving anemia management, particularly by enhancing hemoglobin levels and iron absorption.
results_summary: Synbiotics showed consistent efficacy in improving hemoglobin levels with no heterogeneity, while probiotics also improved hemoglobin and serum iron levels, though prebiotics did not exhibit significant effects. The results suggest synbiotics may be a promising intervention for anemia, but further high-quality RCTs are needed.
population_specificity: Patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA) and anemia of chronic kidney disease (CKD), totaling 632 participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the synbiotic mixture MN-Gup-GOS compared to the probiotic MN-Gup alone on glycemic control in T2DM patients and explore potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The synbiotic MN-Gup-GOS significantly reduced fasting blood glucose (FBG) more than placebo and the probiotic alone, and also improved HbA1c, insulin resistance, inflammation, oxidative stress, gut microbiota, and bile acid levels. The probiotic MN-Gup alone showed some benefits but was less effective than the synbiotic.
population_specificity: 120 T2DM patients (median age 59 years, 40 men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotics or synbiotics on gastrointestinal symptoms (GIS) and Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO) in post-metabolic bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that probiotics did not offer significant benefits in treating GIS or SIBO in post-surgery patients. The meta-analysis included three studies on GIS and two on SIBO, with no substantial improvements observed.
population_specificity: Post-metabolic bariatric surgery patients with GIS or SIBO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of probiotics or synbiotics in reducing chemotherapy-induced complications and gut microbiota dysbiosis in gastrointestinal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that probiotics or synbiotics significantly reduced chemotherapy-related complications like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, and positively altered gut microbiota composition, such as increasing bifidobacterium and decreasing Escherichia coli.
population_specificity: Patients with gastrointestinal cancer undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postnatal synbiotic supplementation could mitigate allergic asthma symptoms in offspring exposed to maternal cigarette smoke and house dust mite allergens.
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation reduced lung resistance, eosinophil counts, Th2 cell activation, and serum IgE and IgG1 levels in HDM-allergic offspring of CS-exposed mothers, while promoting beneficial gut bacteria like Bifidobacterium and Akkermansia.
population_specificity: Offspring of dams exposed to cigarette smoke, challenged with house dust mite allergens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a Synbiotic-Enzyme complex (SEC) could serve as an effective alternative to antibiotics in broilers by assessing its impact on growth performance, carcass quality, intestinal morphology, and immune function.
results_summary: Supplementing broilers with 0.1% SEC significantly improved average daily gains, feed efficiency, body measurements, carcass quality, intestinal villus height, and immune organ indexes compared to control and antibiotic groups.
population_specificity: 864 mixed-sex 1-day-old arbor acres (AA+) broilers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary intervention with synbiotics (trehalose combined with specific probiotics) could alleviate oxidative stress and inflammatory damage in early lactation and improve maternal and offspring outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics composed of 2.5% trehalose and 1 × 10^7 cfu/g of Bifidobacterium longum improved antioxidant and immune abilities, regulated gut microbiota, enhanced mammary gland development, and increased lactation and offspring growth.
population_specificity: Early lactating dams (animal study).
effective_dosage: 2.5% trehalose and 1 × 10^7 cfu/g of Bifidobacterium longum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of synbiotics on reducing seizure frequency in children with drug-resistant epilepsy and the burden on their caregivers.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant decrease in caregiver burden and seizure frequency after synbiotic intervention, with seizure frequency stopping in two patients and decreasing by 50% in six patients.
population_specificity: Thirty children (aged 2-15 years) with drug-resistant epilepsy in Arak, Iran.
effective_dosage: Infants: 5-15 drops of PediLact per day; children (2-15 years): one sachet of KidiLact per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotic preparations on carcass quality, gastrointestinal functional status, ochratoxin A accumulation, and health status in turkeys fed OTA-contaminated diets compared to commercial probiotic additives.
results_summary: Synbiotics reduced digesta pH in certain digestive tract sections, significantly decreased liver weight at weeks 6 and 15, and improved health status while reducing mycotoxin accumulation in organs and tissues. No significant differences were found in growth performance or carcass quality.
population_specificity: 120 female BIG 6 turkeys divided into six treatment groups.
effective_dosage: 0.5 g/kg of synbiotics S1, S2, or S3.
study_duration: Weeks 6 and 15 (specific total duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of synbiotics, alone or combined with vitamin D, on treatment response, cytokine profiles, and hormonal biomarkers in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant therapy.
results_summary: The study found no clear link between synbiotics and pathological complete response (pCR) or Ki-67 index changes. However, combined vitamin D and synbiotic supplementation showed potential synergistic anti-inflammatory effects, notably increasing the anti-inflammatory index and protecting against IL-10 decline.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant therapy in Kerman, Iran (n=76).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of synbiotics on IL-17A levels, disease activity, and inflammatory factors in SLE patients.
results_summary: Synbiotics significantly reduced IL-17A protein and mRNA levels and improved disease activity scores in SLE patients, while the placebo group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
effective_dosage: Not specified (composition included Streptococcus thermophilus, Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus casei, Lactobacillus rhamnosus, Lactobacillus salivarius, Lactobacillus reuteri, Bifidobacterium lactis, Bifidobacterium longum, Bifidobacterium bifidum, and fructooligosaccharides).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of synbiotics in mitigating Alzheimer's disease (AD) by examining their effects on the gut-brain axis and cognitive decline.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics show promise in addressing cognitive decline and reducing the psychological burden of AD, potentially offering a more effective intervention than probiotics or prebiotics alone.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative synbiotic treatment could improve postoperative outcomes, particularly by reducing sepsis, in patients undergoing living-donor liver transplantation with early enteral nutrition.
results_summary: The synbiotic group showed a significantly lower incidence of sepsis (0% vs. 7.4%) and sepsis due to bacteremia with intestinal bacteria (0% vs. 4.6%) compared to the non-synbiotic group, with no significant differences in acute rejection, small-for-size graft syndrome, or liver function.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing living-donor liver transplantation.
effective_dosage: Live lactic acid bacteria, bifidobacteria, and oligosaccharides administered 5 days before and after transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of synbiotics (combinations of probiotics and prebiotics) in treating irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) by reviewing randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trials.
results_summary: Some clinical trials demonstrated promising efficacy results for synbiotics in IBS patients, but data remain sparse, and more high-quality trials are needed to confirm these findings. The review included eight trials (three mono-strain and five multi-strain synbiotic products).
population_specificity: Adult patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of NMN synbiotics in mitigating Alzheimer's disease pathology by reducing amyloid-β deposition, improving intestinal barrier function, and decreasing neuroinflammation and oxidative stress.
results_summary: NMN synbiotics significantly reduced amyloid-β deposition in the brain, improved intestinal barrier integrity, decreased proinflammatory cytokines, and reduced oxidative stress in APP/PS1 mice.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 mice (a model for Alzheimer's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of NMN synbiotics on gut microbiota composition, metabolic profiles, and amyloid plaque reduction in APP/PS1 transgenic mice as a model for Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: NMN synbiotics restructured gut microbiota, reduced the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio, normalized metabolic composition, and significantly decreased amyloid plaques in the brain of AD mice. Functional predictions indicated alterations in pathways related to neurotransmitter synthesis and energy metabolism.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 transgenic mice (Alzheimer's disease model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of probiotics and synbiotics in cancer prevention and their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that probiotics and synbiotics produce chemopreventive compounds that may inhibit cancer cell proliferation, induce apoptosis, and enhance pro-apoptotic gene expression. Synbiotics showed promise in mitigating cancer risk and improving preventive measures.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 7-week synbiotic intervention could improve the gut microbiome in individuals with low dietary fiber intake.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotic supplementation significantly increased the abundance of SCFA-producing microbes in participants with low fiber intake, suggesting improved gut health, while the effect was less pronounced in those with higher fiber intake.
population_specificity: Metabolically healthy males (n = 117, age 32 ± 10 y, BMI 25.66 ± 3.1 kg/m²) with low dietary fiber intake (<25 g/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic impact of prebiotics, probiotics, and synbiotics on surgical outcomes and treatment side-effects in colorectal cancer (CRC) patients undergoing treatment.
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation improved surgical outcomes (e.g., reduced complications, shorter hospital stays) and alleviated chemotherapy/radiotherapy side-effects like diarrhea, though optimal strains, dosage, and duration remain unclear.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer (CRC) undergoing treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of synbiotics supplementation on gut microbial homeostasis during H. pylori eradication therapy and investigate its combined effects with fucoidan.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics supplementation (alone or combined with fucoidan) prevented significant changes in gut microbiota diversity and composition, unlike the control group. The combined QFS group also showed a reduction in harmful bacteria like Klebsiella and no increase in Escherichia-Shigella.
population_specificity: 80 patients with H. pylori infection, divided into four groups of 20 each.
effective_dosage: Not specified (synbiotics contained three strains of Bifidobacterium, three strains of Lactobacillus, and three types of dietary fiber).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Synbiotic preparations in modulating gut microbiota and their impact on Alzheimer's disease (AD) development in mice.
results_summary: Synbiotics treatment significantly improved learning and memory by reducing Aβ protein deposition, modulating gut microbiota, activating PPARs signaling, and reducing neuroinflammation in APP/PS1 mice.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 mice (AD model) and C57BL/6J mice (wild-type control).
